app.stnOverview: Designing, installing, maintaining and supporting communication networks within an organisation or between organisations.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have one of the following:
* A levels * a level 3 apprenticeship or other relevant qualification * relevant experience or an aptitude test with a focus on functional maths
app.stnLearn: * principles of networking, protocols and associated technologies * using diagnostic tools to find the causes of system failure * architecture of a typical business IT system * designing simple networks from specification and optimising performance * installing and configuring network parts, including switches, routers and firewalls * undertaking system upgrades and integrating software into an existing network * interpreting written requirements and technical specifications * logging and responding to network service calls
app.stnQual:
Apprentices must achieve an internationally recognised vendor or professional qualification, selected by the employer.
Apprentices must achieve level 2 in English and maths by the end of their apprenticeship, if they haven’t already done so.
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship is recognised for entry onto the register of IT technicians at Skills Framework for the Information Age (SFIA) level 3.

app.stnOverview: Building and testing simple, high-quality code for software.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have one of the following:
* A levels * a level 3 apprenticeship or other relevant qualification * relevant experience or an aptitude test with a focus on functional maths
app.stnLearn: * software development lifecycle and methodologies * writing code in at least 1 language and creating a user interface for at least 1 channel * linking code to databases * problem solving, testing code and analysing results to correct errors * design: creating data models and software designs * analysis: understanding and creating basic analysis artefacts * deployment: building, managing and deploying code into enterprise environments * applying maths (algorithms, logic and data structures) in software development
app.stnQual: Apprentices must achieve level 2 in English and maths by the end of their apprenticeship, if they haven’t already done so.
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship is recognised for entry onto the register of IT technicians at Skills Framework for the Information Age (SFIA) level 3.

app.stnOverview: Using engineering data and relevant equipment to assemble aircraft systems, testing and adjusting systems to ensure they meet specifications.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 4 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * theory of flight, aerodynamics and aircraft manufacturing processes * electrical, electronic and fluid power theory * structure, properties and characteristics of materials used in building aircraft * reading and interpreting engineering drawings and specifications * designing efficient and cost-effective manufacturing processes * assembly and disassembly of aero components, sub-assemblies and whole systems * safe selection and use of specialist equipment * assembly, sealing and jointing techniques
app.stnReg:
The apprenticeship is recognised at ‘engineering technician’ level by:
*the Institution of Engineering and Technology * the Royal Aeronautical Society * the Institution of Mechanical engineers

app.stnOverview: Ensuring that plant and equipment perform to required standards in manufacturing environments.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 4 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * how to use and interpret a range of engineering data sources and supporting documentation * using lean techniques to improve efficiency and effectiveness * how to support installation, testing and commissioning of a wide range of equipment * complex fault diagnosis and repair on high technology engineered systems * how to minimise machinery downtime by carrying out preventative planned maintenance * confirmation testing and subsequent smooth handover of equipment and plant * knowledge from a range of academic disciplines, including mathematics and engineering
app.stnReg: Completion of this apprenticeship standard will be recognized by the relevant professional institutions as evidence required for engineeering technician (EngTech) registration through a professional review.

app.stnOverview: Installing, maintaining and repairing electrical systems in industrial, commercial and domestic environments.
app.stnLearn: * terminating and connecting conductors, cables and cords in electrical systems * preparing and installing wiring systems and electrotechnical equipment * inspecting, testing, commissioning and certifying of eletrotechnical equipment * diagnosing and correcting electrical faults * selecting equipment and planning its instillation * maintaining electrotechnical systems and equipment
app.stnQual: * Level 3 Electrotechnical Qualification (installation or maintenance) * Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: At the end of the apprenticeship, apprentices can register as en engineering technician (Eng Tech) with the Engineering Council.

app.stnOverview: Constructing, maintaining and repairing the UK’s electrical power network, providing a safe and reliable supply of electricity to the country.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have at least 3 GCSEs at grades A to C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * electrical testing and how to respond to the results of tests * electrical theories applicable to building and maintaining electrical power networks * electrical/mechanical principles and their use in work processes * using maths calculations in power engineering * legislation and regulation * using specialist tools and equipment * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: overhead lines, underground cables, substation fitting
app.stnQual: Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: Successful apprentices will be able to register as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) with the Institution of Engineering and Technology.

app.stnOverview: Providing financial products and services to customers, helping them achieve their business goals.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have A levels or other relevant level 3 qualifications. Employers may also consider relevant prior experience.
app.stnLearn: * ethical standards * product knowledge * risk and governance * market awareness * customer relationships * financial analysis * other skills related to 1 of the following specialisms: corporate, retail, wealth
app.stnQual:
Professional qualifications for this apprenticeship depend on the level of experience in the sector and the parts of the bank the apprentice works in. You can find more details in the apprenticeship standard.
Apprentices without level 2 English and maths must achieve this standard before completing their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg:
Depending on their specialism, successful apprentices will be able to apply for registration with the following organisations:
* retail banking: Chartered Banker Institute, Institute of Financial Services * wealth: Chartered Banker Institute, Institute of Financial Services, Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment, Chartered Insurance Institute * corporate banking: Chartered Banker Institute, Institute of Financial Services, Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) Institute

app.stnOverview: Providing administrative support to a financial organisation, to provide a high quality and compliant service.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 1 of the following:
* level 2 maths and English, ideally as part of 5 GCSEs grades A to C * equivalent qualifications or prior experience
app.stnLearn: * the financial services market * the financial services regulatory framework * ethics and key principles of the financial advice process * the purpose and technical content of financial services products and services * systems and processes required to carry out the role of financial services administrator
app.stnQual:
Apprentices will take a range of professional qualifications, as set out in the apprenticeship standard.
Candidates who don’t have English and maths at grace C or above (or equivalent) will have to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship provides the first step on the pathway to professional membership of the Chartered Insurance Institute, Institute of Financial Services and the Chartered Institute of Securities and Investment.

app.stnOverview: Assuring that manufacturing runs smoothly in areas such as site maintenance.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and a science, technology or engineering related subject * A levels at grade C or above in a maths-based subject and a science, technology, engineering or another maths-related subject (or 90+ credits in an engineering BTEC at level 3)
app.stnLearn: * using and interpreting engineering data * installation, testing and commissioning of equipment and fault diagnosis and repair * maintaining mechanical, fluid and pneumatic power equipment * maintaining electrical, electronic and process control equipment * minimising machinery downtime by carrying out preventative planned maintenance * leading complex maintenance or technical support activities * carrying out testing and calibration of instrumentation control equipment * academic knowledge from a relevant degree
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Supporting the manufacturing of new products by brining the product to life and resolving manufacturing problems.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and a science, technology or engineering related subject * A levels at grade C or above in a maths-based subject and a science, technology, engineering or another maths-related subject (or 90+ credits in an engineering BTEC at level 3)
app.stnLearn: * producing parts using hand fitting techniques * producing electrical or electronic drawings using a computer aided design (CAD) system * preparing and using general and specialist machines and equipment * wiring and testing electrical equipment, and maintaining electrical equipment and systems * assembling and testing electronic circuits * producing engineering plans * engineering project management and working with engineering specifications and briefs * electrical/electronic product manufacturing and testing * academic knowledge from an engineering degree
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Helping take products from design to manufacture, ensuring that they are launched on time, on cost and to the right quality.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and a science, technology or engineering related subject * A levels at grade C or above in a maths-based subject and a science, technology, engineering or another maths-related subject (or 90+ credits in an engineering BTEC at level 3)
app.stnLearn: * producing parts using hand fitting, fabrication and joining techniques * producing drawings using a computer aided design (CAD) system * preparing and using general and specialist machines and equipment * preparing and providing computer numeric control programmes (programmes that control machinery) * using computer software packages to help with engineering activities * producing assemblies using a wide range of materials and techniques * engineering project management, securing resources and managing budgets * implementing, monitoring and evaluating engineering processes
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Using engineering techniques to bring new products to life or redesign existing products.
app.stnEntry:
Set by employer. Candidates will usually have:
* 5 GCSEs at grade C or above (or equivalent) in maths, English and a science, technology or engineering related subject * A levels at grade C or above in a maths-based subject and a science, technology, engineering or another maths-related subject (or 90+ credits in an engineering BTEC at level 3)
An apprenticeship as a product design and development technician also provides a potential preparation route for this standard.
app.stnLearn: * Interpreting, evaluating and using engineering data * producing parts using hand fitting techniques and producing mechanical assemblies * producing electrical or electronic drawings using a computer aided design (CAD) system * using general and specialist equipment, including mechanical, electrical and electronic devices and equipment * managing and controlling product design change * engineering project management * creating design briefs, presenting and discussing technical proposals * academic knowledge from an engineering degree
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnOverview: Helping engineers create and modify products, from early concept feasibility, design and development stages to final preparation for launch.
app.stnEntry: Set by employer. Candidates will usually have 4 GCSEs at grade C (or equivalent), including maths, English and a science.
app.stnLearn: * using and interpreting engineering data * producing parts and prototypes using hand fitting techniques * using general and specialist equipment * producing assemblies and rigs using a range of materials and techniques * applying electrical and electronic principles to products and equipment * identifying, diagnosing and rectifying design problems * using the latest advanced manufacturing technologies * academic knowledge from guided learning
app.stnQual: Employers who recruit candidates without English and maths GCSE grade C (or Functional Skills level 2) or above must ensure that the candidate achieves this level before completion of the apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship has been designed to meet the professional standards of the Engineering Council for initial registration as an engineering technician (Eng Tech) in partnership with the Institution of Mechanical Engineers.

app.stnLearn: * working safely in a laboratory * following quality procedures * regulatory requirements * technical skills to fulfil their role * producing, analysing and interpreting data, and applying statistical techniques * communicating scientific information appropriately * using appropriate scientific methods to identify the causes of problems and produce solutions
app.stnQual:
Apprentices must complete a level 3 or 4 qualification in a science or technology discipline relevant to their occupation and recognised for registration as a registered science technician (RSciTech).
Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: This apprenticeship is recognised by the relevant professional organisations at RSciTech level.

app.stnOverview: Operating the systems and equipment involved in the production of products.
app.stnLearn: * starting, operating and shutting down a manufacturing batch or continuous process * working safely in a science manufacturing environment * quality procedures and standards * complying with regulations * controlling and monitoring a process or plant and equipment * applying relevant science and technology
app.stnQual:
A level 3 or 4 qualification in science or technology that is relevant to their occupation and recognised for registration as a registered science technician (RSciTech) or engineering technician (EngTech).
Apprentices who don’t have level 2 English and maths (or equivalent) will need to achieve this level before the end of their apprenticeship.
app.stnReg: The apprenticeship is recognised by the relevant professional organisations at RSciTech and EngTech levels.
